step_by_step.explanation: Intermolecular forces are forces of attraction or repulsion between molecules.

problems.final_answer: IMFs: forces between molecules affecting physical properties.

problems.problem: List the main types of intermolecular forces.

step_by_step.explanation:
1. London dispersion forces
2. Dipole-dipole forces
3. Hydrogen bonding

problems.final_answer: Main IMFs: London dispersion, dipole-dipole, hydrogen bonding

step_by_step.explanation: Temporary dipoles induced in molecules due to momentary electron density shifts; present in all molecules.

problems.final_answer: London forces: temporary dipoles from electron motion, in all molecules.

step_by_step.explanation: Attraction between permanent dipoles in polar molecules.

problems.final_answer: Dipole-dipole: attraction between polar molecules' permanent dipoles.

problems.problem: Explain hydrogen bonding and give an example.

step_by_step.explanation: Strong dipole-dipole interaction where H is bonded to F, O, or N and attracted to lone pair on another electronegative atom. Example: H₂O

problems.final_answer: Hydrogen bonding: H bonded to F/O/N interacts with lone pair; e.g., H₂O

problems.problem: Rank the following by increasing IMF strength: CH₄, H₂O, HCl.

step_by_step.explanation: CH₄: London; HCl: dipole-dipole; H₂O: hydrogen bonding

problems.final_answer: Increasing IMF strength: CH₄ < HCl < H₂O

problems.problem: Explain how IMFs affect boiling points.

step_by_step.explanation: Stronger IMFs require more energy to separate molecules → higher boiling points.

problems.problem: Compare surface tension of water and hexane and explain why.

step_by_step.explanation: Water: hydrogen bonding; hexane: London forces
Water has stronger IMFs → higher surface tension than hexane

problems.final_answer: Water > hexane in surface tension due to stronger IMFs (H-bonding).

problems.problem: Explain why molecular solids have lower melting points than ionic solids.

step_by_step.explanation: Molecular solids are held together by weak IMFs, while ionic solids are held by strong electrostatic forces.

problems.final_answer: Molecular solids: lower melting points due to weak IMFs; ionic solids: high due to strong ionic bonds.

problems.problem: Predict which is more volatile: CH₃OH or CH₄ and explain why.

step_by_step.explanation: CH₃OH: hydrogen bonding; CH₄: London forces
CH₄ has weaker IMFs → more volatile than CH₃OH

problems.final_answer: CH₄ is more volatile than CH₃OH due to weaker IMFs.
